title: The struggle for life in the Dead Sea sediments: Necrophagy as a survival mechanism

title_detail.value: The struggle for life in the Dead Sea sediments: Necrophagy as a survival mechanism

summary: The Dead Sea is not completely dead. The most saline lake on Earth (more than 10 times saltier than sea water) is a harsh environment where only salt-loving microbes from the Archaea domain, known as extreme halophiles, are able to survive. Geologists are interested in the evolution of this lake and have been investigating its subsurface to reconstruct its biological and geological history.
